data.title: The Psychology of Characters: Giving Depth to Your Protagonists and Antagonists
data.meta_description: Characters drive the narrative in any story. They are the heart and soul of a novel, the vehicle through which a reader travels the landscape of the plot. But to make characters truly compelling…
data.text:
Characters drive the narrative in any story. They are the heart and soul of a novel, the vehicle through which a reader travels the landscape of the plot. But to make characters truly compelling, they must possess depth and complexity. This is where the psychology of characters comes into play, adding layers of authenticity and relatability that resonate with readers. So, how do we imbue our characters with psychological depth?

Understanding Character Psychology

At its core, character psychology is the internal makeup of a character. It’s their motivations, desires, fears, quirks, and personal history that dictate their actions and reactions. It’s not enough for a character to be ‘good’ or ‘evil’; readers crave an understanding of why a character behaves a certain way. A villain isn’t terrifying because of their evil actions, but because we understand their twisted logic and motivations that make those actions possible.

Develop a Character Profile

Begin by building a character profile. This is an in-depth look at the character’s past, present, and future. Where did they come from? What experiences shaped their world-view? What do they want, and what’s stopping them from getting it?

This profile isn’t just about their backstory. It’s about understanding their behaviour, their motivations, and how they handle conflict. When you understand your characters as if they were real people, you can write them in a way that feels authentic and natural.

Emotional Range and Consistency

Characters, like humans, are emotional creatures. They should experience a wide range of feelings that are consistent with their personality and circumstances. When characters react emotionally to the events in your story, it creates a sense of authenticity and deepens the readers’ connection to them.

However, it’s essential to maintain emotional consistency. While characters can and should change over time, these changes need to be gradual and logical. Sudden, unexplained shifts in personality or behaviour can alienate readers and break their suspension of disbelief.

Character’s Internal and External Conflicts

Conflicts are pivotal in revealing a character’s psychology. The way they handle obstacles and adversity can tell us a lot about their personality. A character’s struggle should stem from both external events and their internal fears, insecurities, or desires.

Internal conflict is the struggle within the character’s mind, often involving competing desires or emotions. It can be a moral dilemma, a fear they need to overcome, or an aspect of themselves they’re trying to change. This kind of conflict adds depth to your characters and makes them feel more real and relatable.

Making Characters Change and Grow

A character’s psychological growth is crucial to any narrative. This doesn’t always mean that they change for the better. Sometimes they can grow in a negative direction, or fail to grow at all, resulting in tragic consequences. Regardless, readers should be able to see a character’s psychological journey from the beginning to the end of the story.

The Role of Backstory

A character’s past significantly influences their psychology. Traumatic events, upbringing, relationships, successes, and failures all contribute to a character’s current state of mind. While you don’t need to reveal everything about a character’s past, hints and revelations can add depth and help explain why a character is the way they are.

The Power of Relationships

Relationships can be a mirror into a character’s psychology. How characters interact with others, how they treat them, and how they are affected by them can tell a lot about their personality, values, and desires. Characters should have a variety of relationships, each one revealing a different facet of their psychology.

The Importance of a Well-Developed Antagonist

The antagonist is not just a hurdle for your protagonist to overcome. They are a character in their own right, with their own motivations, fears, and desires. They should be a reflection of what your protagonist could become under different circumstances.

Consider some of the most memorable villains in literature. They are compelling not just because of their evil deeds, but because we understand their motivations, even if we don’t agree with them. This understanding creates tension and conflict and makes the story more compelling.

The Use of Archetypes

Archetypes can serve as useful starting points when developing the psychology of your characters. Archetypes, such as the hero, the mentor, or the trickster, have certain common characteristics that can help you shape your characters. However, remember that archetypes should be used as a foundation, not a mold. Your characters should grow beyond their archetypal roots to become unique individuals.

The Impact of Setting on Character Psychology

Consider the setting and environment your characters are in. A character’s surroundings can greatly impact their psychology. A character raised in a war-torn country will have a vastly different perspective and approach to life compared to a character from a peaceful suburban town.

Show, Don’t Tell

Showing a character’s psychology is more effective than telling. Instead of saying, “John was angry,” show John’s anger through his actions, dialogue, and internal thoughts. This provides a more immersive experience for the reader and allows them to infer a character’s mental state, making the character more realistic and engaging.

The Role of Dialogue

Dialogue is a powerful tool to reveal a character’s psychology. Through dialogue, you can showcase a character’s attitudes, beliefs, desires, and even their past. However, dialogue must be natural and consistent with the character’s personality. An intellectual character will use different vocabulary and sentence structure than a street-smart character.

Remember the Importance of Subtext

Subtext, the unspoken or less obvious message or meaning, can be a powerful way to reveal a character’s psychology. What a character doesn’t say often reveals more than what they do say. The actions they take, the way they react, the things they avoid — these can all hint at a deeper psychology beneath the surface.
